subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 with bea 9.2 workshop
msgSnippet: I have not needed to use suite() much since moving to Eclipse 3.0 (other than when I was using Eclipse 3.1.2 just before Eclipse 3.2 and I started using JUnit
messageBody:
I have not needed to use suite() much since moving to Eclipse 3.0 (other than when I was using Eclipse 3.1.2 just before Eclipse 3.2 and I started using JUnit 4, so all of my classes have suite methods for backwards compatibility with the Runner and ant). When you mentioned the suite thing, it seemed intuitive. I'd say keep it as it. It certainly makes sense in both situations and it's clear.

As for @BeforeSuite/@AfterSuite being more intuitive, I don't agree. It's more to remember.

If a class has a suite method, @BeforeClass happens before that, right? If a class just has a bunch of @Test, then it runs before all of them. What is not intuitive about that?

And if you have both, then what would happen if you had both @BeforeClass and @BeforeSuite? I guess @BeforeSuite would happen before @BeforeClass? But that doesn't seem to make sense since Class is a bigger "container" of stuff than "suite" so now we get unexpected or hard to justify results.

No, I think one set of annotations is wholly adequate, intuitive and simple.

Brett

Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 8/11/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> There are indeed several ways to achieve this with JUnit, but why not simply
> add @BeforeSuite and @AfterSuite? The intent would be much clearer,
> wouldn't it?
>

Maybe. What do people think? For me, @BeforeClass and @AfterClass
already mean "before everything coming from _this_ class", and "after
everything coming from _this_ class", whether that's all the methods on
a test class, or all the classes referenced from a Suite class. This
means that @BeforeClass has a consistent meaning on both suite classes
and test classes. If suite classes have BeforeSuite, and test classes
have BeforeClass, then what does BeforeClass mean on a suite class? What
does BeforeSuite mean on a test class? It seems that fewer concepts is
better.

Thoughts from frequent JUnit users?

David
